article:
:This article is related to the study of self-replicating units of culture, not
to be confused with [[Mimetic]]s.

'Memetics' is a theory of mental content based on an analogy with Darwinian
evolution, originating from the popularization of Richard Dawkins' 1976
book [[The Selfish Gene]]. Burman, J. T.
(2012). The misunderstanding of memes: Biography of an unscientific object,
1976â1999. [[Perspectives on Science]], 20(1), 75-104.
[http://www.mitpressjournals.org/doi/pdfplus/10.1162/POSC_a_00057 ] (This
is an open access article, made freely available courtesy of MIT
Press.) It purports to be an approach to evolutionary models of
cultural information transfer.

The meme, analogous to a gene, was conceived as a "unit of culture" (an idea,
belief, pattern of behaviour, etc.) which is "hosted" in one or more individual
minds, and which can reproduce itself, thereby jumping from mind to mind. Thus
what would otherwise be regarded as one individual influencing another to adopt
a belief is seen—when adopting the intentional stance Discussion between
Jeremy Burman and Tim Tyler, [http://on-memetics.blogspot.com/2012/02/was-there-misunderstanding-of-
memes.html Was there a misunderstanding of memes?] On Memetics. —as
an idea-replicator reproducing itself in a new host. As with genetics,
particularly under a Dawkinsian interpretation, a meme's success may be due to
its contribution to the effectiveness of its host.

Memetics is also notable for sidestepping the traditional concern with the
[[truth]] of ideas and beliefs. Instead, it is interested in their success.

The Usenet newsgroup alt.memetics started in 1993 with peak posting years in the
mid to late 1990s. The Journal of Memetics was published
electronically from 1997 to 2005.
